Article 1. Ownership and Uses of Submerged Lands.

§ 28.2-1200. Ungranted beds of bays, rivers, creeks and shores of the sea to remain in common.

All the beds of the bays, rivers, creeks and the shores of the sea within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth, not conveyed by special grant or compact according to law, shall remain the property of the Commonwealth and may be used as a common by all the people of the Commonwealth for the purpose of fishing, fowling, hunting, and taking and catching oysters and other shellfish. No grant shall be issued by the Librarian of Virginia to pass any estate or interest of the Commonwealth in any natural oyster bed, rock, or shoal, whether or not it ebbs bare.

(Code 1950, § 62-1; 1960, c. 533; 1968, c. 659, § 62.1-1; 1992, c. 836; 1995, c. 850; 1998, c. 427.)

Cross references. - As to certificates issued under § 62.1-44.15 et seq. relating to dredging projects governed under § 28.2-1200 et seq. or § 28.2-1300 et seq., see § 62.1-44.15 (5c).

As to right of riparian owner to dredge sand and gravel from land under water, see §§ 62.1-190 through 62.1-193.

Law review. - For article, "Property Law," see 35 U. Rich. L. Rev. 777 (2001).

Michie's Jurisprudence. - For related discussion, see 8B M.J. Fish and Fisheries, § 3; 14A M.J. Oysters, § 2; 15 M.J. Public Lands, § 4; 20 M.J. Waters and Watercourses, §§ 26, 28.

CASE NOTES

For history of this section, and related statutes, see Miller v. Commonwealth, 159 Va. 924, 166 S.E. 557 (1932); Bradford v. Nature Conservancy, 224 Va. 181, 294 S.E.2d 866 (1982) (decided under former § 62.1-1).

Acquisition of private rights to submerged land. - Private grants of submerged lands have been recognized not only by the common law of England and the decisions of the Supreme Court of Virginia, but the General Assembly has codified this concept in this section. Thus, this section acknowledges that private rights may properly be acquired by lawful grants. Commonwealth v. Morgan, 225 Va. 517, 303 S.E.2d 899 (1983) (decided under former § 62.1-1).

This section is merely declaratory of existing law as commonly received and understood, and it is not a mere arbitrary assumption of right by the state. Taylor v. Commonwealth, 102 Va. 759, 47 S.E. 875 (1904); Newport News Shipbuilding & Dry Dock Co. v. Jones, 105 Va. 503, 54 S.E. 314 (1906); Meredith v. Triple Island Gunning Club, Inc., 113 Va. 80, 73 S.E. 721 (1912) (decided under former § 62.1-1).

Governs use of public waters. - Except for Va. Const., Art. XI, § 3, pertaining to "natural oyster beds, rocks and shoals," use of the public waters of the state is governed generally by this section of the code. Avery v. Beale, 195 Va. 690, 80 S.E.2d 584 (1954) (decided under former § 62.1-1).

Applies to tidal and nontidal waters. - Where it was contended that this section applied only to tidal waters it was held that such a contention was unsound. Schermerhorn v. Dozier, 251 F. 839 (4th Cir. 1918) (decided under former § 62.1-1).

Statute inapplicable to lakes. - This statute specifically enumerates the categories of bodies of water that are subject to its provisions and the precise words of the statute do not include "lakes" within the listed categories. In accordance with the maxim which provides that the mention of a specific item in a statute implies that other omitted items were not intended to be included within the scope of the statute, this section does not apply to Smith Mountain Lake because the general assembly chose not to include "lakes" in its designation of bodies of water whose beds remain the property of the commonwealth in the absence of a special grant or compact. Smith Mt. Lake Yacht Club, Inc. v. Ramaker, 261 Va. 240, 542 S.E.2d 392, 2001 Va. LEXIS 35 (2001).

Rights of riparian owner. - The riparian owner always had certain rights in the adjacent submerged land, such as to enjoy the natural advantage of his location; to use a right-of-way to and from the navigable water; to build a pier or wharf, subject to the regulation of the state; to have the benefit of accretions or alluvium, and to make reasonable use of the water as it flows past his land. However, the common-law rights of the owner of land adjacent to tidal waters were never considered to include the right to remove substances from the soil under water. The common law is, however, subject to modification by statute. United States v. Smoot Sand & Gravel Corp., 248 F.2d 822 (4th Cir. 1957) (decided under former § 62.1-1).

Pursuant to governing law, the property owner's rights only extended to the low-water mark, and no further; title to land between the low-water mark and the line of navigability was in the Commonwealth, to be exercised for the benefit of the people, and, thus, the Commonwealth could and did authorize the State Marine Resources Commission to determine that the property owner's roof and second-story deck added to his private pier without the State Marine Resources Commission's permission or approval violated the governing laws and had to be removed because they were not essential to the private pier's placement for the limited purpose of accessing navigable waters or vessels moored in those waters. Evelyn v. Commonwealth Marine Res. Comm'n, 46 Va. App. 618, 621 S.E.2d 130, 2005 Va. App. LEXIS 428 (2005).

The federal government has no property interest in a harbor bottom which it can convey, since title to the bottom is clearly vested in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Norfolk Dredging Co. v. Radcliff Materials, Inc., 264 F. Supp. 399 (E.D. Va. 1967) (decided under former § 62.1-1).

Title to water beds. - A patent for land constituting a part of the bed of a navigable river, conveys no title to it. Norfolk City v. Cooke, 68 Va. (27 Gratt.) 430 (1876). See also Home v. Richards, 8 Va. (4 Call) 441 (1798); Mead v. Haynes, 24 Va. (3 Rand.) 33 (1824); French v. Bankhead, 52 Va. (11 Gratt.) 136 (1854) (decided under former § 62.1-1).

State Marine Resources Commission's authority. - Commission did not act in an arbitrary and capricious manner when it approved the owner's after-the-fact permit to include an upper deck bar structure on the pier that the owner rebuilt after a hurricane. The commission did not have any decision making formula intended to dictate the outcome of a permit application and, instead, was directed to permit "reasonable uses" of state-owned bottomland pursuant to § 28.2-1204, and permitting the bar structure was acceptable because the pier was open to the public for the public's use and enjoyment. Boone v. Harrison, 52 Va. App. 53, 660 S.E.2d 704, 2008 Va. App. LEXIS 246 (2008).

Applied in Va. Marine Res. Comm'n v. Chincoteague Inn, 287 Va. 371, 757 S.E.2d 1, 2014 Va. LEXIS 51 (2014).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Jurisdiction. - Virginia Marine Resources Commission has jurisdiction over certain state-owned submerged bottomlands. Harrison v. Va. Marine Res. Comm'n, 73 Va. Cir. 111, 2007 Va. Cir. LEXIS 222 (Norfolk 2007), rev'd, Boone v. Harrison, 52 Va. App. 53, 660 S.E.2d 704, 2008 Va. App. LEXIS 246 (2008).

Authority not limited by executive orders. - While Executive Orders 58 and 66 enabled individuals to reconstruct or build replacements for piers and other structures damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Isabel, nothing limited the authority of the Virginia Marine Resources Commission (VMRC) to grant permits to expand or enlarge upon those pre-September 18, 2003, uses. VMRC had authority to exercise jurisdiction over state-owned submerged lands, including to issue permits for reasonable uses thereof pursuant to §§ 28.2-1204 and 28.2-1205. Harrison v. Va. Marine Res. Comm'n, 73 Va. Cir. 111, 2007 Va. Cir. LEXIS 222 (Norfolk 2007), rev'd, Boone v. Harrison, 52 Va. App. 53, 660 S.E.2d 704, 2008 Va. App. LEXIS 246 (2008).

Title to water beds. - Because the waters of a creek were navigable waters, the bed of the creek below the mean low water mark was the property of the Commonwealth. Fleeton Mach. Works, Inc. v. C.W. O'Bier & Sons, Inc., 97 Va. Cir. 353, 2008 Va. Cir. LEXIS 3393 (Northumberland County Oct. 3, 2008).

OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL

Department of Conservation and Recreation may regulate swimming in public parks, natural preserves, and other areas over which the Department exercises supervisory authority, but lacks the authority to regulate swimming in other waters. See opinion of Attorney General to The Honorable Albert C. Pollard, Jr., Member, House of Delegates, 10-074, 2010 Va. AG LEXIS 50 (8/23/10).

Authority of Department of Environmental Quality to approve renewable energy projects. - Because the Department of Environmental Quality is directed to assess whether a submitted application for a small renewable energy project meets the requirements of "the applicable permit by rule regulations," the Department of Environmental Quality may treat the locality certification requirement of subdivision B 2 of § 10.1-1197.6 as inapplicable when a proposed wind project will be located in state waters or on state-owned submerged lands and may authorize a project if the agency determines that the project applicant has met all other applicable requirements. See opinion of Attorney General to Mr. David K. Paylor, Director, Virginia Department of Environmental Quality, 10-091, 2010 Va. AG LEXIS 88 (12/30/10).

§ 28.2-1200.1. Conveyance of state-owned bottomlands.

  1. In order to fulfill the Commonwealth's responsibility under Article XI of the Constitution of Virginia to conserve and protect public lands for the benefit of the people, the Commonwealth shall not convey fee simple title to state-owned bottomlands covered by waters. However, the Commonwealth may grant a lease, easement, or other limited interest in state-owned bottomlands covered by waters pursuant to § 28.2-1208 or as long as the property is used by a governmental entity for the performance of a governmental activity, as defined in §§ 28.2-1300 and 28.2-1400.
    1. The Commonwealth may convey fee simple title to specified parcels of state-owned bottomlands that have been lawfully filled. For the purpose of this section, "lawfully filled" means the deposit of fill was (i) authorized by statute, (ii) pursuant to valid court order, (iii) authorized or permitted by state officials pursuant to statutory authority subsequent to July 1, 1960, or (iv) under apparent color of authority prior to July 1, 1960. In the absence of information to the contrary, it may be presumed that state-owned bottomlands filled prior to July 1, 1960, were filled under apparent color of authority and, it may also be presumed, that all of the fill on the specified parcel was lawfully authorized if a substantial portion of the fill on such parcel was authorized. Properties not qualified under clauses (i) through (iv) of this subdivision shall not be eligible for conveyance under this section. B. 1. The Commonwealth may convey fee simple title to specified parcels of state-owned bottomlands that have been lawfully filled. For the purpose of this section, "lawfully filled" means the deposit of fill was (i) authorized by statute, (ii) pursuant to valid court order, (iii) authorized or permitted by state officials pursuant to statutory authority subsequent to July 1, 1960, or (iv) under apparent color of authority prior to July 1, 1960. In the absence of information to the contrary, it may be presumed that state-owned bottomlands filled prior to July 1, 1960, were filled under apparent color of authority and, it may also be presumed, that all of the fill on the specified parcel was lawfully authorized if a substantial portion of the fill on such parcel was authorized. Properties not qualified under clauses (i) through (iv) of this subdivision shall not be eligible for conveyance under this section.
    2. Titles to lands that (i) were once or may have been state-owned bottomlands covered by waters, (ii) were filled prior to July 1, 1960, and (iii) were acquired by private persons in good faith for value after such lands were filled, are hereby declared to be free and clear of any claimed ownership or interest by the Commonwealth and are released to such private persons and their successors and assigns by the Commonwealth to the extent that the areas of these lands were not state-owned bottomlands covered by waters on July 1, 1960.
    3. This subsection shall not apply to any state-owned bottomlands filled by a publicly funded initiative and put to a continuing public use, which includes beach nourishment projects and public landings.
  3. Except as provided in subsection D, the grantee in a conveyance under subdivision B 1 shall compensate the Commonwealth in an amount commensurate with the property interest being conveyed, which shall be considered equivalent to 25 percent of the assessed value of the specified parcel, exclusive of any buildings or other improvements. The assessed value shall be established as the average of the local real estate tax assessments for the most recent 10 years available for the specified parcel. If no such assessments are available for the specified parcel, then the assessed value shall be calculated as the percentage, by square footage or acreage, that the specified parcel represents of the larger parcel for which such assessments are available.
  4. If the Commission determines that unique circumstances exist, the Commission may allow the grantee in a conveyance under subdivision B 1 to compensate the Commonwealth in an amount less than 25 percent of the assessed value of the specified parcel. Any such determination by the Commission shall be justified in writing and shall not be subject to judicial review.

(2007, c. 879; 2011, c. 734.)

Editor's note. - Acts 2007, c. 879, cl. 2 provides: "That the provisions of this act shall not affect any litigation that is pending on the effective date of this act."

Acts 2011, c. 733 also amended this section but could not be reconciled with Acts 2011, c. 734. The section was set out as amended by Acts 2011, c. 734 at the direction of the Virginia Code Commission.

Acts 2011, c. 734, cl. 2 provides: "That any payments made to the Commonwealth for conveyances of state-owned bottomlands prior to July 1, 2011, shall not be refundable."

The 2011 amendments. - The 2011 amendment by c. 734, effective October 1, 2011, substituted "subdivision" for "subsection" in subdivision B 1; added subdivision B 2 and 3; and inserted "in a conveyance under subdivision B 1" preceding "to compensate the Commonwealth in an amount" in the first sentence of subsection D and rewrote C and D.

Research References. - Friend's Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 27, Property Actions. § 27.09 Ejectment. Friend.

Virginia Forms (Matthew Bender). No. 16-568. Deed of Easement for Foot Wharf Facilities.

CASE NOTES

Applicability. - Although defendant challenged the circuit court's determination that he could not rely upon subdivision B 2 of § 28.2-1200.1 to defeat plaintiffs' claim for ejectment or to establish ownership rights in the bottomlands under the island and causeway, defendant conceded that he did not assign error to this finding. Without reviewing the correctness of the circuit court's determination, the Supreme Court was satisfied that, if correct, it would render the statute inapplicable, and this ground formed a separate and independent basis to affirm the circuit court's ruling. Ferguson v. Stokes, 287 Va. 446, 756 S.E.2d 455, 2014 Va. LEXIS 60 (2014).

OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL

"Public facilities." - Flood control activities are "public facilities" as defined in §§ 28.2-1300 and 28.2-1400, and thus when a local government undertakes a flood control project, it is engaging in "governmental activity." See opinion of Attorney General to Honorable Stephen G. Bowman, Commissioner, Virginia Marine Resources Commission, 19-017, 2019 Va. AG LEXIS ____ (9/6/19).

This section authorizes the Commonwealth to grant an easement over state-owned bottomlands to a local government's flood control project. Section 28.2-1200.1 empowers the Commonwealth to grant easements in state-owned bottomlands without General Assembly oversight over each particular easement. See opinion of Attorney General to Honorable Stephen G. Bowman, Commissioner, Virginia Marine Resources Commission, 19-017, 2019 Va. AG LEXIS ____ (9/6/19).

§ 28.2-1201. Ungranted islands which rise from lands which are property of the Commonwealth.

  1. Except as otherwise provided in subsections B and C hereof, all ungranted islands which rise by natural or artificial causes from the beds of bays, rivers and creeks that are ungranted under § 28.2-1200 shall remain the property of the Commonwealth and shall be managed by the Commission as provided in Article 2 (§ 28.2-1503 et seq.) of Chapter 15 of this title. In case of any conflict between the provisions of this subsection and the common law of accretion, reliction and avulsion, such common law shall control.
  2. Any island or land that is owned by the Commonwealth, whether currently in existence or subsequently created, that now or hereafter abuts a barrier island of the Eastern Shore shall remain the property of the Commonwealth and shall be managed by the Commission as provided in Article 2 (§ 28.2-1503 et seq.) of Chapter 15 of this title.
  3. This section shall not apply to accretions to privately owned lands or islands, whether or not they are used as commons.

(1991, c. 378, § 41.1-4.1; 1992, c. 836; 1995, c. 850.)

Law review. - For note, "As Virginia Strives for a Lead in the Aquaculture Industry, Issues Between Property Owners and Oyster Farmers Rise to the Surface," 32 Regent U.L. Rev. 135 (2019).

§ 28.2-1202. Rights of owners to extend to mean low-water mark.

  1. Subject to the provisions of § 28.2-1200, the limits or bounds of the tracts of land lying on the bays, rivers, creeks, and shores within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth, and the rights and privileges of the owners of such lands, shall extend to the mean low-water mark but no farther, except where a creek or river, or some part thereof, is comprised within the limits of a lawful survey.
  2. For purposes of this section, "lawful survey" means the boundaries of any land, including submerged lands, held under a special grant or compact as required by § 28.2-1200, such boundaries having been determined by generally accepted surveying methods and evidenced by a plat or map thereof recorded in the circuit court clerk's office of the county or city in which the land lies.
  3. Notwithstanding any provision of law to the contrary, where sand or other material is placed upon state-owned beds of the bays, rivers, creeks, or shores of the sea channelward of the mean low-water mark as part of the performance of a properly permitted beach nourishment, storm protection, or dredging project undertaken by a public body, and the public has an established right of use and maintenance upon the adjacent land above the mean low-water mark, whether such public right is established before or after the sand or other material is placed, such placement shall not be deemed a severance or taking of, or otherwise to have impaired, an adjacent landowner's riparian or littoral rights, and the newly created land channelward of the former mean low-water mark shall be deemed natural accretion for purposes of ownership, but such ownership shall be subject to the public's same right of use and maintenance upon the newly created land as previously existed on the adjacent land above the mean low-water mark. This subsection is retroactively effective beginning January 1, 2009.

(Code 1950, § 62-2; 1968, c. 659, § 62.1-2; 1972, c. 865; 1992, c. 836; 2014, cc. 106, 234.)

The 2014 amendments. - The 2014 amendments by cc. 106 and 234 are identical, and added subsection C.

CASE NOTES

Common law. - At common law the title of an owner of land on navigable waters extended only to high-water mark. Thurston v. City of Portsmouth, 205 Va. 909, 140 S.E.2d 678 (1965) (decided under prior law).

For history of this section, and related statutes, see Miller v. Commonwealth, 159 Va. 924, 166 S.E. 557 (1932); Bradford v. Nature Conservancy, 224 Va. 181, 294 S.E.2d 866 (1982) (decided under prior law).

Intent. - This section is intended to give to every riparian owner the right to the water frontage belonging by nature to his land. Generally, this right includes, among others, the right of access to the navigable part of the watercourse, and also the right to the soil under the water between the riparian owner's land and the navigable line of the watercourse whereon he may erect wharves or piers for his own use, or the use of the public, subject to such rules and regulations as governing authorities may deem proper to impose for the public's protection. Cordovana v. Vipond, 198 Va. 353, 94 S.E.2d 295 (1956) (decided under prior law).

Section only applicable where commonwealth owns bed of body of water. - This section defines the boundaries of privately owned land that is adjacent to a body of water whose bed remains the property of the commonwealth under the provisions of § 28.2-1200; it is not relevant to a determination of property rights where the commonwealth is not the owner of the bed of the body of water. Smith Mt. Lake Yacht Club, Inc. v. Ramaker, 261 Va. 240, 542 S.E.2d 392, 2001 Va. LEXIS 35 (2001).

The term "low-water mark" means ordinary low water, not spring tide or neap tide, but normal, natural, usual, customary or ordinary low water, uninfluenced by special seasons, winds or other circumstances. Scott v. Doughty, 124 Va. 358, 97 S.E. 802 (1919) (decided under prior law).

And fee simple title extends to low-water mark. - While at common law the title of the owner of land bounded by a tidal stream extended only to high-water mark, such owner has under this section a fee simple title to low-water mark. Taylor v. Commonwealth, 102 Va. 759, 47 S.E. 875 (1904) (decided under prior law).

It cannot be doubted that in Virginia the title of the landowner runs only to the low-water mark, and that title to the soil under tidal waters is in the state. This is in accordance with the recognized common-law rule and is confirmed by declaratory statutes. United States v. Smoot Sand & Gravel Corp., 248 F.2d 822 (4th Cir. 1957) (decided under prior law).

Course of boundary at low-water mark. - The limits or boundaries of the lands being extended by the law down to low-water mark, it necessarily follows, in the absence of any direction in this section to the contrary, that they must be extended in the same direction that they reach ordinary high-water mark. To extend a limit or bound is to extend a line, and to extend a line is to carry it forward, to prolong it, and to prolong it means primarily to continue it in the same direction. Groner v. Foster, 94 Va. 650, 27 S.E. 493 (1897); Whealton v. Doughty, 116 Va. 566, 82 S.E. 94 (1914) (decided under prior law).

Pursuant to governing law, the property owner's rights only extended to the low-water mark, and no further; title to land between the low-water mark and the line of navigability was in the Commonwealth, to be exercised for the benefit of the people, and, thus, the Commonwealth could and did authorize the State Marine Resources Commission to determine that the property owner's roof and second-story deck added to his private pier without the State Marine Resources Commission's permission or approval violated the governing laws and had to be removed because they were not essential to the private pier's placement for the limited purpose of accessing navigable waters or vessels moored in those waters. Evelyn v. Commonwealth Marine Res. Comm'n, 46 Va. App. 618, 621 S.E.2d 130, 2005 Va. App. LEXIS 428 (2005).

Shifting of boundary with low-water mark. - This section, in terms extends the rights of riparian owners of land on bays, rivers, creeks and shores of the sea to low-water mark. However this line may change either for the advantage or disadvantage of the riparian owner, due to accretion or recession, low-water mark remains his true boundary. The title of the Commonwealth to the public waters likewise shifts with the shifting sands. Steelman v. Field, 142 Va. 383, 128 S.E. 558 (1925) (decided under prior law).

Right to have boundaries defined. - A riparian owner is entitled, in conformity with his rights under this section, to have the extent of his enjoyment upon the line of navigability of the watercourse determined and marked, and his boundaries defined. The right is based upon the principles of equity and a court of chancery is the proper tribunal to make the apportionment and to determine the boundaries between coterminous owners. Cordovana v. Vipond, 198 Va. 353, 94 S.E.2d 295 (1956) (decided under prior law).

Riparian rights may be severed from the land to which they were once appurtenant and dealt with separately and apart therefrom. Thurston v. City of Portsmouth, 205 Va. 909, 140 S.E.2d 678 (1965) (decided under prior law).

Riparian rights appurtenant to highland, whether adjacent to inland streams or tidal waters, may be severed and alienated as a separate property interest. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under prior law).

Where all riparian rights were reserved and severed from the land when the plat was recorded, whatever riparian rights defendants acquired were severed riparian rights when acquired. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under prior law).

By grant or reservation. - Riparian rights may be separated from the ownership of the land to which they are appurtenant, either by a grant of such rights to another, or by a reservation thereof in the conveyance of the land. Thurston v. City of Portsmouth, 205 Va. 909, 140 S.E.2d 678 (1965) (decided under prior law).

Which conveys property right. - There may be a conveyance of water or water rights separate and apart from the land thereunder, and such a conveyance is a conveyance of a property right. Thurston v. City of Portsmouth, 205 Va. 909, 140 S.E.2d 678 (1965) (decided under prior law).

Intention to sever riparian rights must be clear and manifest. - If a landowner selling property intended to sever the riparian rights appurtenant to a lot, it was incumbent upon him to make his intention clear and manifest. Interstate Motels, Inc. v. Biers, 213 Va. 498, 193 S.E.2d 658 (1973) (decided under prior law).

Applied in Jennings v. Bd. of Supervisors of Northumberland County, 281 Va. 511, 708 S.E.2d 841, 2011 Va. LEXIS 85 (2011).

CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS

Land owner does not own property below mean low-water mark. - In a condemnation proceeding condemning a permanent utility easement along the southern boundary of the triplex parcel owned by defendant, because the evidence conclusively established that the gazebo and pier were located below the mean low-water mark, they were not within the boundaries of the triplex parcel as the property was held in public trust by the Commonwealth, and not within the area of any easement in defendant's land; thus, the appellate court would not consider any potential loss of use of the gazebo and pier in calculating the value of the easement. City of Norfolk v. Hedgepeth, 96 Va. Cir. 199, 2017 Va. Cir. LEXIS 117 (Chesapeake July 27, 2017).

Landowners' property did not have riparian rights that would have permitted them to build a pier out to the navigable waterway where a bathymetric study established where the mean low-water (MLW) mark fell, and that study established that the property lines of neighboring properties that extended into the water cut off the landowners' property lines before those lines reached the MLW mark. Smith v. Pope, 102 Va. Cir. 452, 2018 Va. Cir. LEXIS 1289 (Norfolk May 4, 2018).

Property of Commonwealth. - Because the waters of a creek were navigable waters, the bed of the creek below the mean low water mark was the property of the Commonwealth. Fleeton Mach. Works, Inc. v. C.W. O'Bier & Sons, Inc., 97 Va. Cir. 353, 2008 Va. Cir. LEXIS 3393 (Northumberland County Oct. 3, 2008).

OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL

Department of Conservation and Recreation may regulate swimming in public parks, natural preserves, and other areas over which the Department exercises supervisory authority, but lacks the authority to regulate swimming in other waters. See opinion of Attorney General to The Honorable Albert C. Pollard, Jr., Member, House of Delegates, 10-074, 2010 Va. AG LEXIS 50 (8/23/10).

Authority of Department of Environmental Quality to approve renewable energy projects. - Because the Department of Environmental Quality is directed to assess whether a submitted application for a small renewable energy project meets the requirements of "the applicable permit by rule regulations," the Department of Environmental Quality may treat the locality certification requirement of subdivision B 2 of § 10.1-1197.6 as inapplicable when a proposed wind project will be located in state waters or on state-owned submerged lands and may authorize a project if the agency determines that the project applicant has met all other applicable requirements. See opinion of Attorney General to Mr. David K. Paylor, Director, Virginia Department of Environmental Quality, 10-091, 2010 Va. AG LEXIS 88 (12/30/10).

§ 28.2-1203. Unlawful use of subaqueous beds; penalty.

  1. It shall be unlawful for any person to build, dump, trespass or encroach upon or over, or take or use any materials from the beds of the bays, ocean, rivers, streams, or creeks which are the property of the Commonwealth, unless such act is performed pursuant to a permit issued by the Commission or is necessary for the following:
    1. Erection of dams, the construction of which has been authorized by proper authority;
    2. Uses of subaqueous beds authorized elsewhere in this title;
    3. Construction and maintenance of congressionally approved navigation and flood-control projects undertaken by the United States Army Corps of Engineers, the United States Coast Guard, or other federal agency authorized by Congress to regulate navigation, navigable waters, or flood control;
    4. Construction of piers, docks, marine terminals, and port facilities owned or leased by or to the Commonwealth or any of its political subdivisions;
    5. Except as provided in subsection D of § 28.2-1205, placement, after submission of an application to the Commission for review and processing, of private piers for noncommercial purposes by owners of the riparian lands in the waters opposite those lands, provided that (i) the piers do not extend beyond the navigation line or private pier lines established by the Commission or the United States Army Corps of Engineers, (ii) the piers do not exceed six feet in width and finger piers do not exceed five feet in width, (iii) any L or T head platforms and appurtenant floating docking platforms do not exceed, in the aggregate, 400 square feet, (iv) if prohibited by local ordinance open-sided shelter roofs or gazebo-type structures shall not be placed on platforms as described in clause (iii), but may be placed on such platforms if not prohibited by local ordinance, and (v) the piers are determined not to be a navigational hazard by the Commission. Subject to any applicable local ordinances, such piers may include an attached boat lift and an open-sided roof designed to shelter a single boat slip or boat lift. In cases in which open-sided roofs designed to shelter a single boat, boat slip or boat lift will exceed 700 square feet in coverage or the open-sided shelter roofs or gazebo structures exceed 400 square feet, and in cases in which an adjoining property owner objects to a proposed roof structure, permits shall be required as provided in § 28.2-1204;
    6. Agricultural, horticultural or silvicultural irrigation on riparian lands or the watering of animals on riparian lands, provided that (i) no permanent structure is placed on or over the subaqueous bed, (ii) the person withdrawing water complies with requirements administered by the Department of Environmental Quality under Title 62.1, and (iii) the activity is conducted without adverse impacts to instream beneficial uses as defined in § 62.1-10; or
    7. Recreational gold mining, provided that (i) a man-portable suction dredge no larger than four inches in diameter is used, (ii) rights of riparian property owners are not affected, (iii) the activity is conducted without adverse impacts to instream beneficial uses as defined in § 62.1-10, (iv) the activity is conducted without adverse impacts to underwater historic properties and related objects as defined in § 10.1-2214, and (v) the activity is not defined as mining in § 45.2-1200.
  2. A violation of this section is a Class 1 misdemeanor.

(Code 1950, § 62-2.1; 1960, c. 600; 1962, c. 637; 1966, c. 641; 1968, c. 659, § 62.1-3; 1970, c. 621; 1972, c. 866; 1973, cc. 23, 361; 1974, cc. 92, 385; 1975, c. 431; 1976, c. 579; 1980, c. 253; 1982, c. 102; 1988, c. 868; 1992, c. 836; 1998, c. 605; 2000, c. 167; 2001, c. 234; 2003, c. 973; 2006, c. 507; 2007, c. 25; 2020, c. 806.)

Cross references. - As to Oyster Replenishment Fund, see § 28.2-542.

As to punishment for Class 1 misdemeanors, see § 18.2-11.

Editor's note. - Effective October 1, 2021, " § 45.2-1200" was substituted for " § 45.1-180" to conform to the recodification of Title 45.1 by Acts 2021, Sp. Sess. I, c. 387, at the direction of the Virginia Code Commission.

The 2000 amendments. - The 2000 amendment by c. 167 inserted "the" preceding "United States Coast Guard" in subdivision A 3, and added "Except as provided in subsection D of § 28.2-1205" at the beginning of subdivision A 5.

The 2001 amendments. - The 2001 amendment by c. 234, in subsection A, deleted "or" at the end of subdivision 4, inserted "or" at the end of subdivision 5, and added subdivision 6.

The 2003 amendments. - The 2003 amendment by c. 973, in the first sentence of subdivision 5, inserted the clause (i) designation, and inserted clauses (ii) through (iv).

The 2006 amendments. - The 2006 amendment by c. 507, in subdivision A 5, inserted "and finger piers do not exceed five feet in width" in clause (ii), in clause (iii) substituted the language beginning "platforms and appurtenant" for "construction platforms or protrusions do not exceed 250 total square feet," inserted clause (iv), redesignated former clause (iv) as clause (v), and in the last sentence, substituted "open-sided roofs designed to shelter a single boat, boat slip or boat lift" for "such roofs" and inserted "or the open-sided shelter roofs or gazebo structures exceed 400 square feet."

The 2007 amendments. - The 2007 amendment by c. 25 added A 7 and made related changes.

The 2020 amendments. - The 2020 amendments by c. 806, in subdivision A 5, inserted "after submission of an application to the Commission for review and processing" in the first sentence and made stylistic changes.

CASE NOTES

This section creates a right which did not exist at common law, viz., the right to fill subaqueous beds. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

It conditions the new right upon either (1) a permit of the Marine Resources Commission or (2) statutory authority. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

"Property" refers to the ripus. - "Property" as the General Assembly used it in this section clearly refers not to an amorphous concept but to a res, the ripus, the bank adjacent to a watercourse. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

And plainly "opposite" was not intended to be synonymous with "upon." Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

So construed, the clause "to any lawfully established bulkhead line" would be meaningless. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

Severed riparian rights, so long as they remain severed, confer no right to fill. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

An owner of severed riparian rights does not have a right to fill equivalent to that of an owner of highland with appurtenant riparian rights. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

And legislature was aware of this when section enacted. - When the legislature enacted this section, it was aware that Virginia law recognized two types of riparian owners, that it chose between the two, and that it conferred the new right to fill only upon the owner of highland with riparian rights appurtenant thereto. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

But fee simple absolute may revive by merger of property interests. - When a property interest severed by an antecedent owner from the fee is acquired by a subsequent owner of the limited fee, the two property interests merge to revive the fee simple absolute. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

Marine Resources Commission lacked authority to determine riparian rights. - The Marine Resources Commission, in granting a permit for the construction of piers, wharves, boat slips, and the like, lacked authority to determine the riparian rights of adjacent landowners inter se, and its action in granting a permit had no res judicata effect upon claims asserted by the landowners. Zappulla v. Crown, 239 Va. 566, 391 S.E.2d 65 (1990) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

State Marine Resources Commission's authority. - Pursuant to governing law, the property owner's rights only extended to the low-water mark, and no further; title to land between the low-water mark and the line of navigability was in the Commonwealth, to be exercised for the benefit of the people, and, thus, the Commonwealth could and did authorize the State Marine Resources Commission to determine that the property owner's roof and second-story deck added to his private pier without the State Marine Resources Commission's permission or approval violated the governing laws and had to be removed because they were not essential to the private pier's placement for the limited purpose of accessing navigable waters or vessels moored in those waters. Evelyn v. Commonwealth Marine Res. Comm'n, 46 Va. App. 618, 621 S.E.2d 130, 2005 Va. App. LEXIS 428 (2005).

Trial court did not err in affirming the Virginia Marine Resources Commission's decision to deny the property owner's after-the-fact permit application to allow a storage shed to remain on the pier that the property owner was allowed to run from his property to a creek; substantial evidence in the record supported the agency's decision that the shed was not necessary. Palmer v. Commonwealth Marine Res. Comm'n, 48 Va. App. 78, 628 S.E.2d 84, 2006 Va. App. LEXIS 121 (2006).

Virginia Marine Resources Commission had authority to regulate a floating platform attached to a restaurant since the platform was an encroachment on the state's subaqueous bottomland, was not authorized by permit or exemption, and was not an inherent public right to navigation. Va. Marine Res. Comm'n v. Chincoteague Inn, 287 Va. 371, 757 S.E.2d 1, 2014 Va. LEXIS 51 (2014).

County has authority to regulate construction of mooring slips and piers. - Circuit court properly denied a landowner relief in its declaratory judgment action challenging the authority of a county board of supervisors to regulate the construction of additional mooring slips and accompanying piers that would lie beyond the mean low-water mark of a creek because the county's zoning authority embraced the entirety of the landowner's proposed construction, even the portion that extended into the Chesapeake Bay's tidal tributaries, i.e., creek; the regulatory authority granted the Virginia Marine Resources Commission by the General Assembly does not preclude, but rather contemplates, that the Commission and a locality will have concurrent authority to regulate the construction of piers upon state-owned bottomlands where the pier is also erected along the waterfront of such locality. Jennings v. Bd. of Supervisors of Northumberland County, 281 Va. 511, 708 S.E.2d 841, 2011 Va. LEXIS 85 (2011).

OPINIONS OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL

Authority of Department of Environmental Quality to approve renewable energy projects. - Because the Department of Environmental Quality is directed to assess whether a submitted application for a small renewable energy project meets the requirements of "the applicable permit by rule regulations," the Department of Environmental Quality may treat the locality certification requirement of subdivision B 2 of § 10.1-1197.6 as inapplicable when a proposed wind project will be located in state waters or on state-owned submerged lands and may authorize a project if the agency determines that the project applicant has met all other applicable requirements. See opinion of Attorney General to Mr. David K. Paylor, Director, Virginia Department of Environmental Quality, 10-091, 2010 Va. AG LEXIS 88 (12/30/10).

Authority of localities to regulate state-owned submerged lands. - Virginia localities do not have the authority to extend the application of their land use ordinances to state-owned submerged lands, therefore, for small renewable energy projects located on or in the waters above state-owned bottomland, there are no "applicable land use ordinances" for purposes of the certification requirement of subdivision B 2 of § 10.1-1197.6. See opinion of Attorney General to Mr. David K. Paylor, Director, Virginia Department of Environmental Quality, 10-091, 2010 Va. AG LEXIS 88 (12/30/10).

§ 28.2-1204. Authority of Commission over submerged lands.

The Commission is authorized to:

  1. Issue permits for all reasonable uses of state-owned bottomlands not authorized under subsection A of § 28.2-1203, including but not limited to, dredging, the taking and use of material, and the placement of wharves, bulkheads, and fill by owners of riparian land in the waters opposite their lands, provided such wharves, bulkheads, and fill do not extend beyond any lawfully established bulkhead lines;
  2. Issue permits to recover underwater historic property pursuant to §§ 10.1-2214 and 28.2-1203; and
  3. Establish bulkhead and private pier lines on or over the bays, rivers, creeks, streams, and shores of the ocean which are owned by or subject to the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth for this purpose, and to issue and publish maps and plats showing these lines; however, these lines shall not conflict with those established by the United States Army Corps of Engineers.

(Code 1950, § 62-2.1; 1960, c. 600; 1962, c. 637; 1966, c. 641; 1968, c. 659, § 62.1-3; 1970, c. 621; 1972, c. 866; 1973, cc. 23, 361; 1974, cc. 92, 385; 1975, c. 431; 1976, c. 579; 1980, c. 253; 1982, c. 102; 1988, c. 868; 1992, c. 836.)

Cross references. - As to Oyster Replenishment Fund, see § 28.2-542.

CASE NOTES

This section creates a right which did not exist at common law, viz., the right to fill subaqueous beds. Commonwealth v. Forbes, 214 Va. 109, 197 S.E.2d 195 (1973) (decided under former § 62.1-3).

Evelyn v. Commonwealth Marine Res. Comm'n, 46 Va. App. 618, 621 S.E.2d 130, 2005 Va. App. LEXIS 428 (2005).

Commission did not act in an arbitrary and capricious manner when it approved the owner's after-the-fact permit to include an upper deck bar structure on the pier that the owner rebuilt after a hurricane. The commission did not have any decision making formula intended to dictate the outcome of a permit application and, instead, was directed to permit "reasonable uses" of state-owned bottomland pursuant to § 28.2-1204, and permitting the bar structure was acceptable because the pier was open to the public for the public's use and enjoyment. Boone v. Harrison, 52 Va. App. 53, 660 S.E.2d 704, 2008 Va. App. LEXIS 246 (2008).
